Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Adaptive Information: Sequential Sensing and Active Learning Theory, Methods and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Complex systems, such as living cells and the Internet, involve interactions and associations between large numbers of individual components. Specific examples include interactions between proteins in biological cells and connections between users in communication networks. Developing theory and methods to model and analyze large-scale networked systems is a grand challenge for the 21st century. For instance, new mathematical methods will lead to better models of biological systems and thus improvements in disease prevention. Measuring the signals of such systems is a crucial step in developing good models, and a major hurdle is that it is often impractical or impossible to measure all variables in large systems. This project addresses the hurdle by developing adaptive methods that automatically adjust the measurement process by using information gleaned from previously collected data in order to focus and optimize the gathering of new information. Ultimately, these methods will dramatically accelerate the pace of discovery in science and engineering.

The main theme of the project is an investigation of the role of adaptive measurement, sensing and experimentation in large complex systems of many variables. Adaptive methods are sequential procedures that optimize the selection of the next measurements or experiments based on previously gathered data. The research involves the development of a general theory for adaptive measurement that is applicable to various domains of engineering and science. The main goals are to mathematically characterize and quantify the advantages of adaptive measurements relative to non-adaptive methods and to design optimal adaptive measurement procedures. The investigation also explores the potential of adaptive methods by studying specific problems and applications in biology, national security, and human-computer interaction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Complex systems involve interactions and associations between large numbers of variables. Ex- amples include biological cells, communication networks, and social media. Developing theory and methods to model and analyze large-scale networked systems is a grand challenge for the 21st century. A major hurdle is the fact that it is often impractical or impossible to simultaneously measure all variables in large systems. To overcome this hurdle, a great deal of recent research in signal processing, applied mathematics, machine learning and statistics has focused on using random measurement techniques. Such randomized and related non-adaptive measurement procedures, however, are often impractical and nearly always suboptimal. In contrast to non-adaptive methods, adaptive methods adjust the measurement process using information gleaned from previously collected data, offering significant advantages. These adaptive methods are the focus of the project.  This project developed a general theory applicable to various domains of engineering and science. The results of this project mathematically characterize the capabilities and limits of sensing and learning, in both adaptive and non-adaptive settings. The proposal applied the results to applications in biology, networking and communications, social media and human-computer interaction.  The research project resulted in the following outcomes: 1) a novel mathematical framework for adaptive sensing and sequential learning; 2)  new algorithms for that sequentially and adaptively select sensing actions or experiments to maximize the gain of new information; 3) publicly available data and software. The project activities also resulted in the following broader impacts: 1) multi- disciplinary training of graduate and undergraduate students; 2) advanced research training of women and other underrepresented groups; 3) student participation in interdisciplinary conferences and meetings, and involvement in undergraduate teaching activities; 4) research dissemination via conferences and journal publications; 5) extension of proposed theory and tools to diverse applications involving similar signal processing challenges, ranging from the analysis of biological systems to communication networks; 6) the transfer new theory and methods to practice, both in academia and industry; 7) new educational development at both the undergraduate and graduate levels.
